8. Investment Program Summary
The project will improve the quality and reliability of electricity supply, reduce the aggregate technical and commercial (ATC)
losses in electricity distribution, and restore the financial sustainability of the rural electricity supply. These will be achieved by (i)
converting low-voltage distribution lines to aerial bundle conductors (ABCs), separating the 11-kilovolt (kV) feeders supplying
agriculture consumers from those supplying rural households to facilitate the rationing of electricity supply to agriculture
consumers, (ii) improving the financial management of Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited, and (iii) deepening community
engagement to improve electricity supply cost recovery and gender inclusivity in rural electricity distribution-related activities.
Impact: Quality and financial cost recovery in the power supply in Uttar Pradesh improved (24X7 Power for All)
Outcome: Efficiency, reliability, and sustainability of power supply in selected rural areas improved
Outputs: (i) Rural electricity distribution network improved, (ii) Systems for separating electricity distribution for agriculture
consumers and for residential consumers established,  and (iii) Systems for bill collection in rural areas and financial
management improved and gender-sensitive workplaces created
Implementation Arrangements: Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) will be the executing agency.
Project Readiness: All works and consulting contract award has been approved by ADB. The project management units have
been established at the executing agency and implementing agency level.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to India for the Uttar Pradesh Power Distribution Network 
Rehabilitation Project. The report describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Enhancing 
Community Participation, Gender Mainstreaming, and Institutional Capacity Building of Uttar 
Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL); and if the Board approves the proposed MFF, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The  project  will  improve  the  quality  and  reliability  of  electricity  supply,  reduce  the 
aggregate technical and commercial (ATC) losses in electricity distribution, and restore the 
financial sustainability of the rural electricity supply. These will be achieved by converting low-
voltage distribution lines to aerial bundle conductors (ABCs), separating the 11-kilovolt (kV) 
feeders supplying agriculture consumers from those supplying rural households to facilitate the 
rationing of electricity supply to agriculture consumers, improving the financial management of 
UPPCL, and deepening community engagement to improve electricity supply cost recovery and 
gender inclusivity in rural electricity distribution–related activities. 
 
II.  RATIONALE 
 
3.  Access to electricity. Uttar Pradesh, India’s most populous state with close to 220 million 
people, has a poverty rate (29%), higher than the national average (21%) and suffers from lack 
of economic opportunities. In FY2018, its per capita electricity consumption of about 400 kilowatt-
hours (kWh) was lower than the national per capita consumption of 960 kWh.2 UPPCL added 8 
million rural connections and 1 million urban consumers from 2017 to 2019, raising the rural and 
urban consumer base to 17 million and 9 million, respectively under the SAUBHAGYA scheme 
supported by government of India.3 With the completion of this scheme, Uttar Pradesh has 
substantially advanced the “energy for all” objective with a household electrification rate of over 
80% in 2020 compared to around 55% in 2016.   
  
4.  Affordability of electricity and cost recovery. The Uttar Pradesh government has the 
policy of subsidizing the electricity supply to its poor consumers, and maintained the lifeline tariff 
(for consumption below 100 kWh/month) for residential consumers at ₹3.35/kWh compared with 
the supply cost of ₹7.85/kWh. Based on the socio-economic survey undertaken during project 
preparation, this rate is considered affordable for the poor with estimated expenditure outlay of 
$200/month/household to meet 60 kWh/month electricity requirement of a typical poor household. 
In  addition,  the  electricity  tariffs  for  residential  consumers  consuming  above  the  lifeline 
consumption and agriculture consumers for water pumping are also maintained below cost 
recovery level. UPPCL, a state-owned enterprise responsible for bulk power purchase and power 
distribution in Uttar Pradesh, required about ₹60 billion fiscal transfer to cover its cost of electricity 
supply in FY2018.  
 
5.   Furthermore, UPPCL has low collection efficiency, collecting only 77% of billed revenue 
in FY2019. Collection efficiency in rural areas is below 50%, mainly due to rural households’ poor 
payment discipline. Agriculture consumers are supplied by unmetered connections and billed a 
fixed monthly charge based on normative electricity consumption linked to the contracted water

pump capacity. The tariff regime does not provide any incentive to conserve electricity, and 
surveys indicate that farmers tend to overuse electricity. 
 
6.  Technical issues of electricity distribution. The rural electricity supply in Uttar Pradesh 
is  characterized  by  (i) frequent  power  interruptions  and  (ii)  an  overloaded  and  dilapidated 
electricity distribution network. From 2011 to 2019, the Government of India’s Deen Dayal 
Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana (DDUGJY) scheme4 and its precursors provided ₹190 billion in 
grants and loans to UPPCL to improve the rural medium-voltage distribution network (33 kV and 
11 kV), including separating the 11 kV feeders supplying residential consumers from those 
supplying agriculture consumers in selected areas. Although these investments have improved 
the medium-voltage network, the rural distribution network still requires investment of about ₹60 
billion. 
 
7.  The investments under the DDUGJY as well as SAUBHAGYA schemes have led to 
improved average supply duration in rural Uttar Pradesh from 12–13 hours/day before 2017 to 
16–18 hours/day in 2019. However, rural electricity supply is still saddled with low performance 
of  distribution  infrastructure,  overuse  of  electricity  by  agriculture  consumers,  low  collection 
efficiency, and poor service to customers. ATC losses stood at 36.8% across Uttar Pradesh in 
FY2019. The poor quality of electricity supply is one of the contributory factors to low socio-
economic development in Uttar Pradesh compared to more progressive states in India. The 
proposed project is designed to resolve long-standing technical and financial management issues 
that continue to significantly hamper electricity sector performance. The project is the first 
investment in Uttar Pradesh’s electricity sector financed by an external development partner since 
2001. 
 
8.  Coronavirus disease impacts. As a result of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic, India’s economy is projected to contract by 9% in the fiscal year 2020/21, before 
rebounding sharply with  8.0% growth in FY2021/22, assuming the pandemic wanes in 2021.5 
With revenue falling sharply  and expenditure rising to fight the pandemic and support the 
economy, the fiscal deficit at both central and state level is expected to rise  sharply in FY 2020/21. 
The government of India has arranged a liquidity injection facility to overcome the short-term 
cashflow  constraints  of  distribution  companies  such  as  UPPCL  due  to  COVID-19-related 
economic downturn, and to enable the timely payment to generation companies by distribution 
companies.  The  proposed  project  will  complement  post-COVID-19  recovery  efforts  by  the 
government by providing (i) short-term benefits through construction-related jobs including to 
migrant workers who were displaced by containment measures; (ii) medium-term improvement to 
UPPCL’s performance, reducing the need for fiscal subsidies; and (iii) long-term benefits through 
improved electricity supply, attracting investments to industry and commerce. The fiscal space 
created  by  reduced  fiscal  subsidy  requirement  to  the  power  sector  will  enable  the  state 
government to allocate additional resources to poverty reduction and social safety nets. 
 
9.  Sector road map. The Government of India and the Uttar Pradesh government have 
agreed on a sector road map under the Ujwal DISCOM Assurance Yojana (UDAY) scheme for 
UPPCL’s financial turnaround through debt restructuring and operational efficiency improvement 
in 2016.6 The UDAY road map consists of (i) a financial restructuring plan to improve UPPCL’s 
debt sustainability, and (ii) an operational improvement plan. The UDAY road map sets out key

performance indicators for UPPCL to rectify its structural weaknesses (paras. 4–7): (i) reduction 
in ATC losses from 42.6% in FY2016 to 15.0% by FY2020; and (ii) complete elimination of the 
gap between the average cost of supply (ACS) and the average revenue realized (ARR) by 
FY2020, which stood at ₹0.43/kWh in FY2016.7  
 
10.  In line with UDAY’s financial restructuring plan, the Uttar Pradesh government took over 
75% of UPPCL’s debt, totaling ₹392 billion (as of September 2015, the outstanding debt was ₹532 
billion). The government then transferred that amount back to UPPCL and its DISCOMs in the 
form of equity (₹98 billion), a grant (₹196 billion), and interest-free loans (₹98 billion). The 
exercise, completed on 31 March 2017, significantly reduced financial losses in FY2016 and 
FY2017.  
  
11.  Under  UDAY’s  operational  improvement  plan,  several  operational  measures,  and 
investments to reduce ATC losses are under implementation, along with the measures supported 
under DDUGJY. UPPCL has entered into an agreement with Energy Efficiency Services Limited 
to install 4 million smart meters in urban areas, of which more than 1.35 million had been installed 
as of 31 July 2020.8 Since 2018, UPPCL has also installed more than 8.5 million conventional 
meters in rural areas to convert unmetered connections to metered ones; the remaining 2 million 
rural consumers will have metered connections by 31 March 2021. All new consumers connected 
since 2017 have metered connections that enable the poor to maintain their monthly electricity 
consumption at an affordable level. All 11 kV feeders are now metered and subjected to regular 
energy audit to identify feeders with high ATC losses and requiring corrective action. 
 
12.  The above measures reduced ATC losses from 42.6% in FY2016 to 36.8% in FY2019 but 
raised the ACS−ARR gap from ₹0.43/kWh in FY2016 to ₹0.74/kWh in FY 2019. The expansion 
of distribution network and addition of large number of rural consumers under SAUBHAGYA 
scheme have adversely impacted the progress in ATC loss reduction and narrowing of ACS−ARR 
gap, while delayed tariff adjustment in 2019 also widened the ACS−ARR gap. In partnership with 
ADB, UPPCL intends to undertake investments towards achieving the performance targets 
specified under UDAY, including (i) completing segregation of 11 kV feeders supplying unmetered 
agriculture consumers from those supplying residential consumers, which is a prerequisite for 
restricting  the  duration  of  electricity  supply  to  the  separated  feeders  supplying  agriculture 
consumers; and (ii) converting rural low voltage distribution lines to ABCs to prevent illegal 
connections.  
 
13.  The project is designed to enable UPPCL to undertake the investments described in para. 
12 to achieve the key performance indicators of UDAY road map. Implementation of the project, 
including  the  financial  management  action  plan  (FMAP)  along  with  other  measures  being 
implemented as above, is expected to enable UPPCL to reduce ATC losses to 14.9% and 
eliminate the gap between ACS and ARR by FY2029, originally targeted to be achieved by 
FY2020  under the  UDAY  memorandum  of  understanding. Improved cost  recovery  of rural 
electricity supply resulting from the project will enable UPPCL to increase supply duration in rural 
areas.9 The improved electricity supply will expand non-farm employment opportunities for the 
rural poor. Reduced fiscal transfers to the electricity sector because of improved cost recovery 
will enable the Uttar Pradesh government to allocate additional fiscal resources for poverty

in  pilot  testing  the  mobilization  of  community  agents,  including  women’s  self-help  groups 
(WSHGs),10 to collect electricity bills.  
 
14.  Policy framework. The policy and regulatory framework governing the electricity sector 
in India and Uttar Pradesh aims to promote least-cost electricity supply and full cost recovery 
through appropriate electricity tariffs, coupled with revenue subsidies from the state government. 
The Uttar Pradesh Electricity Regulatory Commission (UPERC) regulates the electricity sector in 
Uttar Pradesh. UPERC determines the tariffs for different consumer categories to recover ACS 
after allowing for certain level of cross subsidies from industrial and commercial consumers to 
agriculture and residential consumers. The Uttar Pradesh government has decided to keep the 
tariff below the cost recovery level for residential consumers using less than 100 kWh/month and 
for agriculture consumers. It has been compensating UPPCL through statutory transfers as 
required under the Electricity Act, 2003 to supply electricity to poor households and agriculture 
with a tariff below the ACS. 
 
15.  UPERC determines the aggregate revenue requirement of UPPCL to provide adequate 
cashflows to meet the eligible expenses based on certain normative efficiency standards and earn 
a regulated rate of return on the equity capital. However, because of operational inefficiencies 
and the prevalence of unmetered connections, UPPCL does not operate at the normative 
efficiency standards set by UPERC for ATC losses. The regulatory framework is designed to 
encourage UPPCL to operate at the  normative efficiency standards stipulated by UPERC, 
however UPPCL’s underperformance in reducing ATC losses and improving collection efficiency 
is resulting in financial losses. The proposed investments under the project will provide substantial 
assistance to UPPCL to improve its operational performance and meet UPERC’s normative 
efficiency standards. This will enable UPPCL to eliminate the gap between ACS and ARR and 
reduce its financial losses. 
 
16.  Strategic context. Improving the rural electricity distribution and ensuring cost recovery 
in electricity sector are recognized as key developmental challenges in India due to its impacts 
on rural economic development and the state’s fiscal sustainability. The proposed project is 
closely aligned with all three pillars of ADB’s country partnership strategy for India11 on (i) boosting 
economic competitiveness by expanding infrastructure networks through improved electricity 
distribution in rural Uttar Pradesh; (ii) providing inclusive access to electricity network to poor and 
vulnerable in rural areas in Uttar Pradesh; and (iii) addressing climate change by reducing the 
wasteful energy and water consumption in agriculture and residential sectors through illegal use 
of electricity. It is also consistent with the recent Independent Evaluation Department’s Sector-
Wide Evaluation of ADB Energy Policy and Program, 2009−2019 which recommended ADB to 
increase  the  support  to  sector  reforms  and  distribution  network  enhancement  to  promote 
operational efficiency improvement. The project is included in ADB’s country operations business 
plan, 2021–2023 for India.12  
  
17.  Alignment with ADB Strategy 2030. The project is aligned with five operational priorities 
(OP) of ADB Strategy 203013 (table 1).

III.  THE PROJECT  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
18.  The project is aligned with the following impact: quality and financial cost recovery in the 
power supply in Uttar Pradesh improved.14 The project will have the following outcome: efficiency, 
reliability, and sustainability of power supply in rural areas improved.15 
 
B.  Outputs 
 
19.  Output 1: Rural electricity distribution network improved. This will consist of 22 
subprojects that will convert 65,000 km of rural voltage distribution network from bare conductors 
to ABC in about 46,000 rural habitations in Uttar Pradesh (each with more than 1,000 people) 
with a total population of about 70 million. Rural communities, including women, will be trained on 
safe and efficient use of electricity. These measures will improve the reliability and safety of 
electricity distribution, and boost cost recovery by discouraging illegal connections.  
 
20.  Output 2: Systems for separating electricity distribution for agriculture consumers 
from residential consumers established. This will consist of 13 subprojects to separate  11 kV 
feeders  (1,100  feeders  with  a  total  length  of  17,000  km),  that  supply  273,000  agriculture 
consumers and 2.42 million households. A parallel network of 11 kV feeders, with a total length 
of about 17,000 km, will be built under this component to connect the distribution transformers 
supplying residential consumers, while using the existing 11 kV feeders to supply agriculture 
consumers. The project will enable UPPCL to increase the duration of power supply to rural 
households from 18 hours/day to 22–24 hours/day and control the supply duration to agriculture 
consumers to match the seasonal water requirement. The expected result is reduced wastage of

electricity  and  water  and  decreased  financial  and  fiscal  burden  of  supplying  electricity  to 
unmetered agriculture consumers. 
 
21.  Output 3: Systems for bill collection in rural areas and financial management 
improved,  and  gender-sensitive  workplaces  created.  The  attached  TA  will  finance  (i) 
supporting  the  implementation  of  FMAP16 to  improve  UPPCL’s  corporate  governance;  (ii) 
strengthening the capacity of UPPCL and its subsidiary DISCOMs to manage accounts receivable 
by, for example, reconciling receivable balances, conducting aging analysis, and developing a 
provisioning policy for the accounts receivable; (iii) developing and pilot testing innovative pro-
poor bill collection strategies involving active participation of 1,000 rural individuals, including rural 
women’s self-help groups (WSHG) as collection agents; and (iv) pilot testing gender-sensitive 
workplace practices and improving working conditions for contractual workers, especially women, 
in 10 contractors of UPPCL.  
 
22.  Use of multitranche financing facility. These outputs are best financed by an MFF to 
achieve the outcome.17 The Uttar Pradesh government has a well-structured sector road map and 
policy framework to improve the quality, reliability, and financial sustainability of electricity supply, 
as described in the UDAY memorandum of understanding (footnote 6). Although the targets set 
in the memorandum of understanding have not been met within the stipulated time frame, UPPCL 
has  initiated  the  agreed  measures  and  the  Government  of  India  closely  monitors  their 
implementation. ADB’s long-term engagement through the project will provide financing certainty 
during the MFF period to UPPCL and the contractors while minimizing the risk to the state 
government of project implementation delays and the resulting financial charges. The MFF 
modality provides a framework for ADB to monitor the implementation progress of the sector road 
map, consistency of subprojects with the policy framework, and project implementation over the 
duration of the MFF.  
 
23.  The project consists of two tranches, time-sliced on  disbursement basis, and divided into 
35 subprojects, of which 26 will be financed by ADB under the MFF and 9 by UPPCL using 
counterpart funds. The implementing agencies have already awarded the contracts for the nine 
subprojects (under output 1) to be financed with counterpart funds, using national procurement 
procedures. Out of the 26 subprojects to be financed by ADB under tranche 1, 13 subprojects will 
support output 1 (para. 19) and 13 subprojects will support output 2 (para. 20). Each subproject 
covers project activities in 3–4 administrative districts. The MFF modality using time-sliced, 
disbursement-based tranches enables the approval of ADB financing under tranche 2 to be linked 
to progress in contract execution and disbursement. 
 
24.  Scope of tranche 1. All 26 ADB-financed subprojects (as described in para. 23) will be 
started under tranche 118 and continued under tranche 2 by the same contractor procured under 
tranche 1. This will ensure that tranche 1 project activities will be representative of the overall 
project, and that tranche 1 will cover 70% of the MFF ceiling amount. The nine subprojects 
financed from  counterpart funds,  and  output  3  to  be financed  by  the  attached  TA  will  be

V.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
35.  ADB staff members undertook technical due diligence of the project to establish the need 
to rehabilitate the distribution network by (i) converting the low-voltage network to ABCs, and (ii) 
separating the 11 kV feeders supplying residential consumers from those supplying agriculture 
consumers. Electricity  distribution companies in several Indian states have converted their low-
voltage networks to ABCs and successfully reduced technical and commercial losses in electricity 
distribution. Feeder separation enables the DISCOM to control the duration of electricity supply 
to agriculture consumers to limit overconsumption by unmetered agriculture consumers. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
36.  Economic analysis.  ADB staff members conducted the economic analysis of the project 
following ADB guidelines. The analysis evaluated the economic costs and benefits in FY2019 
constant  prices  for  FY2020–FY2050.  The  economic  benefits  mainly  come  from  behavioral 
changes to conserve electricity induced by project interventions as described in the economic 
analysis.24 The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated by comparing the with- and 
without-project scenarios. The project is economically viable with an EIRR of 14.5%, and the 
project’s expected net present value is ₹22.6 billion at an economic discount rate of 9.0% per 
year. The sensitivity of the EIRR was assessed for the following adverse scenarios: (i) insignificant 
consumer behavior changes, (ii) reduction in the generation cost, and (iii) reduction in willingness 
to pay for electricity. The project’s economic viability is robust under these adverse scenarios. 
 
37.  Financial analysis. The financial analysis of the project followed ADB’s guidelines for 
financial management and analysis of projects.25 The analysis did not quantify COVID-19’s 
financial and economic impacts as these are expected to last 12–18 months and  will not 
significantly affect the project over its lifetime. However, sensitivity analysis has been run on 
possible project implementation delays because of COVID-19. The project’s estimated financial 
internal rate of return in real terms is 10.38% compared with the project’s weighted average cost 
of capital in real terms of 4.0%. ADB staff members performed an analysis to assess the sensitivity 
of the financial internal rate of return to adverse changes in key variables, including (i) less-than-
expected decrease in distribution losses, (ii) increase in operation and maintenance costs, and 
(iii) delay in project completion. The results of the sensitivity analysis confirmed the project’s 
financial viability under these adverse scenarios.

38.  UPPCL’s historical financial performance (FY2015–FY2019) and financial projections 
(FY2020–FY2029) are summarized in the financial analysis (footnote 25). UPPCL’s financial 
losses were ₹70 billion and accounts receivable totaled ₹689 billion in FY2019. Key factors that 
adversely affect UPPCL’s financial performance include (i) low collection efficiency that has led 
to a buildup of an unsustainable level of accounts receivable, contributing to an operating cash 
flow deficit and inability to timely settle power purchase dues, and compelled UPPCL and its 
subsidiaries to borrow additional funds for working capital; (ii) distribution loss exceeding the 
norms set by UPERC for tariff determination, leading to higher power purchase cost which is not 
allowed to be recovered from approved tariff by UPERC; and (iii) a highly leveraged debt position 
that has made it difficult for UPPCL to service its debt obligations. UPPCL’s weak financial status 
precludes private financing of the sector. 
 
39.  UPPCL has agreed on key financial covenants in the loan agreement26 to progressively 
improve its financial health. The covenants will help ensure that UPPCL (i) is able to service its 
debt obligations in a timely manner; (ii) increases its collection efficiency and progressively brings 
down its accounts receivable; (iii) receives adequate equity injections from the state government 
to finance capital expenditure, reduce its leverage, and strengthen its financial position; and (iv) 
submits annual requests for tariff revision. The project supports various technical measures that 
UPPCL is implementing to reduce ATC losses, reduce the accounts receivable from 498 days of 
revenue billed in FY2019 to 90 days of revenue billed in FY2029, and lower its power purchase 
requirements. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
40.  UPPCL’s operations and tariffs are regulated by UPERC. UPPCL subsidiary companies, 
the project’s implementing agencies, have limited autonomy and UPPCL manages their finances. 
UPPCL has successfully implemented several large projects financed by domestic financial 
institutions, such as Power Finance Corporation and Rural Electrification Corporation, under 
government procedures. However, UPPCL’s overall pre-mitigation financial management risk is 
substantial because of unreconciled interunit and intercompany balances, the lack of a completed 
fixed assets registry, high levels of accounts receivable, delays in annual external audits, and 
inadequate internal control systems. 
 
41.  A breach of fiduciary management of the Uttar Pradesh State Power Sector Employees 
Trust (UPSPSET)27 was exposed in 2019.  UPSPSET financial assets were allegedly invested in 
a  nonbank  financial  institution  without  requisite  approvals  from  UPSPSET  trustees,  and 
UPSPSET might lose a significant amount of its assets because of the liquidation of the nonbank 
financial institution. UPPCL has informed ADB that it will take actions to strengthen UPSPSET’s 
fiduciary management and prevent similar incidents. Actions include (i) the election of employee 
representatives  to  the  UPSPSET  board  of  trustees  and  investment  committee,  (ii)  strict 
compliance with investment norms stipulated by the Government of India for pension funds, and 
(iii) the provision of online information on UPSPSET’s investment performance. 
 
42.  UPPCL with the assistance of ADB prepared an FMAP to improve UPPCL’s corporate 
governance and financial management as described in the FMA.28 Key time-bound actions to 
improve corporate governance include (i) appointing independent directors to the UPPCL board,

D.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
45.  Uttar Pradesh’s rural areas are plagued by a lack of jobs, high labor migration to urban 
areas such as Delhi, and water stress because of depleted groundwater. A large proportion of the 
areas’ population lives below the poverty line. The project will improve the quality, reliability, and 
duration of electricity supply in selected rural areas, which would encourage investment in industry 
and commerce, and creation of employment opportunities for the poor. Proposed revisions to the 
Electricity Act, 2003 require the state government to make direct cash transfers to subsidize the 
lifeline consumption of the poor. The direct cash transfers will alleviate the short-term impacts on 
the poor caused by enforcement of payment discipline and prevention of illegal connections.29 
 
46.  Gender.  Tranche  1  of the MFF  is  categorized  effective  gender mainstreaming  and 
incorporates specific measures as described in the gender action plan.30 The project will pilot test 
engaging rural women through WSHG as community collection agents and use of incentive-based 
compensation scheme for the collection agents. The project will develop UPPCL’s institutional 
capacity  to  promote  gender  equality  and  social  inclusion,  including  establishing  gender-
responsive human resource practices for UPPCL staff members and contract workers. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
47.  Following the special MFF requirements in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), 
ADB, in consultation with UPPCL, prepared a safeguard assessment and review framework 
(SARF).31 The SARF combines the requirements of an environmental assessment and review 
framework,  and  a  resettlement framework  as  the  environmental  and social  impacts  of the 
subprojects are anticipated to be limited. The SARF provides guidance to UPPCL and the 
implementing  agencies  on  environmental  and  resettlement  safeguard  due  diligence  to  be 
undertaken during project implementation. ADB has disclosed the SARF on the ADB website.

49.  Involuntary resettlement (category B). The project involves installing 11 kV distribution

distribution lines will follow the right-of-way of the roads in most cases, but might require installing 
electricity poles on private land in some cases (less than 2%) and only after obtaining the consent 
of the private landowners. Impacts will be avoided and mitigated, and compensation will be given 
for the residual impacts. ADB has prepared a resettlement plan33 for the project based on a 
representative sample survey of project activities for the 11 kV feeder separation component. 
 
50.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project areas are not inhabited by indigenous 
populations, and the project will not impact indigenous peoples.

The project will improve the quality and reliability of electricity supply, reduce the aggregate technical and commercial (ATC) losses in electricity distribution, and restore the financial sustainability of the rural electricity supply.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated November 2020 is provided for the ADB project 51395-002 in India.
